pr_title: PROF-1560: Fix simple type constant pool handling

timeline.bodyText:
nit: I was expecting for a bool a something like computedHashCode
if you want to express the need to computeHashCode, maybe: needsComputeHashCode or
isComputedHashCode`
timeline.author: jpbempel

replies.bodyText: Yep. Lost-in-translation - I meant computeHashCode?, but yes I will change the name
replies.author: jbachorik

timeline.bodyText:
optional: volatile is not require here, like for string this is a benign race.
worst case you compute hashcode couple of  times for concurrent requests
timeline.author: jpbempel

replies.bodyText:
I was pondering this - however, without volatile there is no guarantee that the hashCode value will ever be visible to other threads/cores (since it is not volatile itself).
Perhaps making hashCode volatile instead would make the intention more clear? The number of load/store points would be exactly the same.
replies.author: jbachorik

replies.bodyText:
I would consider the hashCode field as a cache, and if reading/writing to it without any volatile is good enough for the String implementation in the standard library, then I think it's good enough for this code as well.
One could use 0 as an illegal/uninitialized hashCode and compute/assign it if it's 0 and skip the extra boolean.
replies.author: bantonsson

timeline.message:
PROF-1560: Fix simple type constant pool handling

Also fix equals/hashCode for all types participating in metadata and constant pool.
Add test for expected number of samples
Include back the 'id' field in equals/hashCode computation of BaseType
Include back the 'id' field in equals/hashCode computation of BaseType

timeline.bodyText: Is this guaranteed to not be 0?
timeline.author: bantonsson

replies.bodyText:
One could use 0 as an illegal/uninitialized hashCode and compute/assign it if it's 0 and skip the extra boolean.

I thought you knew :)
Most probably it is not guaranteed. A hash computation may easily return 0 and would not be breaking the contract. But Objects.hash() is assigning '0' to null values. In this case non null values will have most probably != 0 hash - unless some hand-crafted hashCode method of a sub-element returns negative values.
replies.author: jbachorik

replies.bodyText: Yeah, it seems unlikely, but the calculation in  Objects.hash(...) could over/under-flow. I would guard against it by bumping a 0 hash to something else, but maybe that's a bit defensive?
replies.author: bantonsson

replies.bodyText: Maybe a bit - the calculation can overflow but if all references are using the same algorithm it would take a very deep tree or enormous amount of fields.
replies.author: jbachorik

replies.bodyText: Added a NonZeroHashCode utility class to generate non-0 hashcodes.
replies.author: jbachorik

timeline.bodyText: This seems to be some thingy that lombok is planning to add automatically - what is the point of using this manually?
timeline.author: mar-kolya

replies.bodyText:
Excluding the method from code coverage test. There is no other way to instruct jacoco not to check certain methods.
And having to write all-combinations tests for equals and hashCode (what should be the test for hash code after all?) - because the class is so simple even single branch miss will make the check fail - is a huge PITA.
replies.author: jbachorik

replies.bodyText: I see... mind adding something like //To skip coverage checks to such lines so people like myself would stop asking stupid questions?
replies.author: mar-kolya

replies.bodyText: Good idea on using annotation, btw!
replies.author: mar-kolya

replies.bodyText: FWIW I've used https://jqno.nl/equalsverifier/ in the past to actually verify equals and hashCode - and it is quite simple to use
replies.author: mar-kolya

replies.bodyText:
Ah, thanks! Will take a look at the tool!
In the meantime I added comments.
replies.author: jbachorik

timeline.bodyText: What is the point of this annotation? If the whole class was generated with some tool could you please add some comments explaining how it was made in case we need to do this in the future?.
timeline.author: mar-kolya

timeline.bodyText: I think we should use accessors instead of public fields. There is zero downside and apart from being tradition this also makes easier to track how these are used.
timeline.author: mar-kolya

replies.bodyText: Ok, not really related to this change but I converted the fields to getters.
replies.author: jbachorik

timeline.message: Update missed references to Annotation fields
